One of the most overrated games ever. It boils down to a fight over wood, cuz you need wood to build 80% of your farm. By the time everyone is done fighting for wood in the first rounds, you wasted the opportunity to get food for your family, and you starve. By the time you actually get a decent working engine, the game is over. Plus, if you play this with the same people, it just turns into the same game every time. Everyone just keeps doing the same things in every game. If you play with new people, if becomes lopsided cuz the new people don’t know any of the strategies. Then they don’t want to play again. If this sounds like fun to you, then give it a try. Not for me, though.

I revisited this in 2021 after a long break, when it went online at BoardGameArena. This was a game I never loved back in the day, but liked enough. So I was a little surprised how much I *hated* it, playing it again now. There are a lot of reasons that are hard to catalog in a short BGG comment block, but I think the big one is just how totally screwed you can be by the turn order. Taking the start player space is very expensive unless you have good, usable minor improvements in hand so getting dealt a few of these vs none is a huge deal both in terms of your chances of victory as well as your ability avoid grinding frustration. I’m also reminded of playing with a friend who consistently highly overvalued the importance of going first, so would frequently take the start player even if he was going second; if he was sitting on your right you were just utterly and completely screwed. And this is just one thing about the game.

Anyway. I never need to play this again.

You assign workers to spaces on the board to gain ressources, then spend ressources to gain victory points. This is done in a dry, repetitive and heads-down fashion, where players tinker with their individual boards and merely interfere with each other. If you have played 'hobby' board games over the past few years, this probably sounds like something you have seen countless times.

And Agricola is no different. The main activity consists of counting with restricted pieces and further restricting each others' actions with blocking the ones already taken. The overall impression is that it feels like a problem to solve and the task is closed, i.e. the optimal path is always calculable.

Emotional and creative involvement is low - All I can remember out of a dozen plays is the nice physicality of a developed tableau and the simple enjoyment of placing sheep on pastures. This is actually one nice apect of the game. When it's finished, the fully equipped game board tells a story. It's just not a particularly entertaining or memorable story.

In the context of later releases it appears comparatively tense and more focussed, but it's still a non-interactive and mentally demanding excercise about learning a scoring system.
Playing this gives me anxiety and that isn't why I play board games.
In my opinion, the best thing that Agricola had going for it was its capacity for interesting storytelling. The actual gameplay part was unfortunately pretty annoying.

I respect the game but I don't like the difficulty of putting card combos together. It's possible I might like it more solo, but I don't think I'd prefer it over Nusfjord or even Glass Road at that count.

Somewhat overwhelming to trudge through, and punishes you harshly if you don't cover all your bases; probably a bit like running a real farm. Occasionally satisfying when your plans come together, but for the most part it's a game that beats you over the head with reasons why you can't do things, instead of giving you fun things that you can do.

What I like:
- Lots of variability through training and small improvements.
- There is always so much more you want to do, but cannot. So you have to prioritise hard and think a few turns ahead.
- The family support mechanism adds a real element of tension to the game. You might want to do something else, but getting some sheep or fish instead for a quick food boost can give you some freedom of choice in the next few rounds.
- Quite interactive in the sense that you have to watch out for other players and sometimes block certain action spaces.

What I dislike:
- Sometimes I wish the game was a bit shorter.
- It's quite fiddly to place new resources on the action board each turn.
- Still, not the most interactive. I think solely about my actions instead of keeping track of the special abilities of other players. Usually a no go for me and probably one of the reasons I'm currently not eager to play the game.
- New players will be absolutely destroyed by more experienced players.

Why I culled it:
I played it quite often with a friend, but the steep learning curve and long-ish playing time led to a state, in which I never seriously thought about proposing to play it with others.

Agricola is a classic and a top 100 game on BGG. I respect it, but I don't enjoy it.

It's a tight game with a thin margin for survival. There's variety, provided by the occupation cards, the order in which spots are revealed, and the actions taken by the players. But those aren't impactful enough for me to feel like the game is meaningfully different between plays. The differences are too small.

Those differences are still impactful. They'll make the game play out differently, especially for experienced players. But I don't find them interesting.

See my thoughts about other Uwe Rosenberg games in my Uwe Rosenberg Games I've Played geeklist.

Classic game that introduced me to worker placement and is still the go to for a highly competitive, pure and rich experience in that genre.

Love how tight the board is and how every action counts, both your own and your opponents. Has a fairly unique cadence, tough to do what you want, tight on resources. As you get better at the game you start to handle this better, but it never goes away. Honestly love this feeling, the game genuinely feels challenging and rewarding, but you kind of have to be in to mood for it. You need to really be prepared to dial in and focus and try to win or you can really get wrecked. Overall I will generally prefer more permissive and casual designs, but when I want a fight for survival feel, none does it better.

Variable setup and cards add a lot of variety to each play. Combining those card powers together is as interesting and satisfying as any game I have ever played. Probably the only flaw though is that this is compromised by the intense focus you need to put into getting your 3rd worker ASAP, this makes part of the early game the same the vast majority of the time, which is a shame. There is a module to fix this, but people then get so many workers so easy that the accumulation spaces never get very full and overall the game is less interesting by far.

Despite everything it does soo well, Agricola is absolutely a sometimes food for me but a game I will always want to pull out from time to time.

Sobre o manual eu entendi a ideia de tentar mesclar o ensinamento das regras com comentários descontraídos do próprio Uwe, mas na prática achei que acabou ficando um pouco prolixo, atrapalhando mais do que ajudando quando se trata de localizar regras rapidamente no meio da partida. A indicação das cartas de Ofício que se deve usar na preparação, de acordo com a quantidade de jogadores, ficou levemente confusa para a coisa simples que é;

A produção deixou a desejar, pois jogando de mesa cheia (quatro jogadores), constantemente faltaram recursos de Madeira e Barro durante a partida. E nem mesmo as fichas multiplicadoras davam conta (só tem uma de cada tipo), o que foi extremamente inconveniente, e senti que a depender das cartas de Ofício e Pequenas Melhorias que os jogadores usarem, isso pode se agravar e também ocorrer com os outros recursos. Fiquei perplexo quando percebi que o manual, além de não citar nada sobre a raridade dessa ocorrência, ainda por cima me diz simplesmente para improvisar. Ou seja, contente-se com essa mesquinharia de componentes e se vire com o que faltar. Na minha visão algo bastante preocupante, pois se o jogo se propõe a ser até quatro jogadores, então ele deveria sim ter componentes suficientes para jogar tranquilamente nesta contagem, de forma a tornar a falta de componentes algo muito raro de acontecer ou no mínimo disponibilizar uma quantidade bem maior de multiplicadores. Vi outras pessoas reclamando disso também aqui no fórum, e infelizmente vi também pessoas normalizando essa bizarrice, colocando inclusive a culpa nos próprios jogadores por supostamente serem menos experientes. Loucura!

O tempo de partida informado na caixa "aproximadamente 90 min" não é lá tão honesto, pois de mesa cheia (4 jogadores) ele facilmente atinge 2 horas (é possível constatar isso também observando os tempos das partidas em quatro jogadores registrados aqui e na Ludopedia). Não é dos piores casos, mas seria mais assertivo se fosse por exemplo "aproximadamente 120 min";

É um jogo relativamente simples, mas que também possui bastante detalhes de regras, que podem ser facilmente esquecidas se não tiver pelo menos uma pessoa experiente na mesa. O que condiz com seu peso atual de cerca de 3,5 na escala BGG;

O jogo é muito fluído, com downtime baixo, pois as jogadas são curtas e não desencadeiam jogadas subsequentes, como ocorre em jogos como SETI, por exemplo. Característica essa que me ganha facilmente. Ponto para o Agrícola;

Interação entre os jogadores agradável, com sensação de cobertor curto.

Apesar de ter deixado a desejar na questão da produção que citei antes, sua imersão e coesão temática são boas, com componentes em formatos específicos dos animais e alimentos; cartas de Ofício e Melhoria, cada uma com sua ilustração própria; peças de cômodo para aumentar a casa do fazendeiro; peças de terra arada que são usadas para simular o processo de cultivo que passa pela preparação do solo, semeadura, produção e colheita, que inclusive param de dar frutos se você não fizer a manutenção plantando novas sementes; a família crescendo e se perpetuando; os animais procriando; e até a possibilidade de ter um pet etc. Elementos que remetem bastante a uma vida bucólica no campo. Dá para sentir mesmo a atmosfera de uma fazendinha sendo gerida para fins de subsistência;

8/10: First the bad then the good. This game is packed full of redundancy and irrelevancy. The bottom half of the major improvements board is almost never used. The bake bread action is horribly inefficient since it can only be done with a single bread, as opposed to cooking animals which can be done with an infinite supply (as long as you have them). The game is extremely samey, as every game will feel like 95% similar to each other, with only mild changes from game to game, with the tiny alterations of the cards that you begin with. Those cards - of which even though you start with 14 - you will be lucky to play a tiny fraction of them. With all that said, this game is simply charming, building out a little farm and watching it grow, and when it comes to taking actions I can think of no tighter game. The first player token has never felt as important in a game as it does in this one, with every move tense and every decision calculated. A choice in one location can lead to a sacrificed position in another. A really interesting efficiency puzzle!

Lot of variety in strategies based on occupation and minor improvement draft at the start of the game, very nice for replayability. Great player interaction where blocking spaces causes big shifts in what people can do

Even after all these years it still feels fresh. The 14‑round limit keeps the game tight and forces tough choices every turn. I love the tension between long‑term planning and short‑term survival — especially the constant pressure of feeding your family.
That said, the rulebook could be clearer (some key details are buried in the appendix), and the card design feels dated. But once you get past the learning curve, the depth and replayability are outstanding.
For me, Agricola remains a must‑play classic that deserves its spot in the BGG Top 100.

An excellent farming simulation game that expertly implements theme and mechanics in board game form. In contrast to Fields of Arle (the only other Uwe game I’ve played), Agricola is tightly focused with tension and crunchiness in its decision space between expansion and sustainability. The cards ensure good variability and replayability. For the genre of game it is, there’s good indirect interaction around the scarcity of resources and contested worker placement spots. This feels solid at 2 players which is great.

While I think the cards make for good variability, I could still envisage this becoming a bit rote and procedural after a number of plays. There’s a fairly repetitive arc around worker placement decisions which restricts varied and creative play to some extent. But perhaps that’s the nature of the beast, which is executed very well. Turns and rounds are delightfully fast, and the central worker placement mechanic is very elegant. The thematic immersion of expanding and sustaining a medieval farm is strong.

A big frustration is the rulebook(s), which I think are poor and an unfortunate barrier to learning the game. It’s a confusing organisation of the rules and some decent player aids would help a lot.

Just clinches a 9/10 for me.

This is a thematic gamer's chess. Great balance of strategy and tactics with infinite replayability using additional decks.

It is streamlined through the improved graphic design & easy interlocking boards for different player counts. The cards have been tested and balanced thousands of times thanks to digital versions. There are so many great variations that can grow with you in complexity (family version, side job tile, card draft, etc, etc). I enjoy Caverna too, but if both versions of Agricola were combined it would easily be ranked higher.

Should you get it? It depends what you and your group want to play. For me, Agricola All Creatures Big and Small gets played more due to it's speed and Caverna's sandbox feeling is more my style.
